description:
13th Annual Latin American Matters (LAM) Forum - Shaping the Future: Climate Resilience, Energy Transition in Latin America
April 17, 2025

The 13th edition of the Annual Latin American Matters (LAM) Forum will take place on April 17, 2025, under the timely and urgent theme "Shaping the Future: Climate Resilience, Energy Transition in Latin America." This year’s forum will bring together students, scholars, policymakers, and practitioners to discuss the region’s evolving response to climate change and its shift toward renewable energy. Through panels, keynote talks, and open discussions, the forum aims to explore innovative policy solutions, regional cooperation, and sustainable development strategies that can drive meaningful change across Latin America.
speaker: The forum will feature at least twelve speakers, primarily from Latin America, including women and members of underrepresented groups

expense name: Caste and Labor Intersectionality: Gender, Religion, and Economic Marginalization
description: Join us for a panel discussion hosted by the Anti-Caste Policy Students Forum (ACPF) in collaboration with the South Asian Students and Policy Association (SASPA) at the Harris School of Public Policy, University of Chicago, on March 25th. This event will explore the intersection of caste, labor, and socio-economic structures, with a focus on gender and religious minorities. Featuring Prof. Ayra Idrias Patras (Pakistan) and Dr. Ansari(India), the panel will shed light on caste-based labor exploitation, democratic deepening, and anti-caste movements across South Asia and beyond.
speaker: TRUE

expense name: Understanding Caste-Based Labor Economy: India and the Diaspora
description: The caste system continues to shape labor markets and economic hierarchies, not only in India but also within South Asian diaspora communities worldwide. Join the Anti-Caste Policy Students Forum (ACPF) at the Harris School of Public Policy for an in-depth discussion on how caste operates as an enduring structure of labor exploitation, intersecting with gender, religion, and class. This event will also examine how caste-based labor discrimination manifests in global contexts, including the United States, where increasing awareness has led to policy debates around caste protections in workplaces and institutions. By analyzing both Indian and diasporic perspectives, the discussion aims to unpack caste as a transnational policy issue embedded within broader systems of inequality.
speaker: TRUE

expense name: Race, Caste, Inequities, and Tech: Power, Access, and the Chaotic Terrain of Policy
description:
This event explores how structural inequities shaped by race and caste continue to influence access, empowerment, and mobility in today’s world. Through the lens of technology and policymaking, we critically examine how marginalized communities navigate and challenge systems of exclusion, while also grappling with technology’s chaotic and dual role. Tech can serve as a powerful tool for empowerment—but it can equally reinforce existing inequities through algorithmic bias, digital divides, and exclusionary design. Together, we will unpack how intersecting identities impact opportunities, how technology both disrupts and perpetuates inequities, and how more inclusive, accountable policymaking can shape a future centered on justice and meaningful social change        

In collaboration  with Asian Policy Forum
speaker: TRUE

expense name: Screen of Movie Origin (2023) : Caste, Cinema, and Social Justice
description:
The Anti-Caste Policy Students Forum (ACPF) is proud to co-host this screening of *ORIGIN (2023), a powerful exploration of caste and systemic oppression across global contexts. This event aligns with ACPF’s mission to critically engage with caste in public policy and governance. Through the film and discussion, we aim to highlight the intersections of caste, race, and social justice in policymaking. We invite students and faculty to reflect on historical injustices and contemporary policy responses. Join us in fostering a dialogue on dismantling caste hierarchies through informed policy action.
The event is collaboration with Asian Policy Forum.
speaker: TRUE

expense name: Restoring American Supply Chains: A Conversation with Thomas Day
description: Join us for an engaging discussion with Thomas Day, a leading expert on American supply chain resilience and national security. As geopolitical tensions with China intensify—marked by escalating tariffs, trade disputes, and a renewed emphasis on domestic manufacturing—the importance of securing and revitalizing American supply chains has never been more critical. Thomas will delve into the national security implications of foreign supply chain dependencies and discuss strategies for restoring American manufacturing capabilities. This conversation is particularly relevant for those interested in global trade, economic security, and industrial policy.
collabhso: Yes, in partnership with the Rural American Caucus, given the topic's direct relevance to rural communities and their economies.
speaker: YES (Not woman, POC, and People with Disability)

expense name: U.S. Decoupling Energy from China: A Policy Conversation with Samir Mayekar
description: As the U.S. faces growing calls to reduce its reliance on Chinese-controlled energy technologies—ranging from solar panels to critical minerals and battery components—this event asks a fundamental question: Should the U.S. pursue energy decoupling? Join Samir Mayekar, former Deputy Mayor of Chicago and a leader at the intersection of public policy and private infrastructure, as he offers a top-down analysis of the risks, tradeoffs, and unintended consequences of energy decoupling. With global climate goals, domestic industrial policy, and national security all on the line, Mayekar will unpack what a strategic energy future might look like—and whether decoupling is part of it.
collabhso: TRUE - Harris Energy and Environmental Association
speaker: TRUE (Samir Mayekar: Woman and POC)

description: The Black Policy Review will launch its second annual publication in May. AWPC will be one-day, ticketed, and held in the Keller Center. This conference is open to all BAPPS members, alumni, the broader Harris community, and the larger University community. description: The Black Policy Review is a student-run publication housed in BAPPS that aims to uplift Black voices and Black stories. Our publication exists to center Black people in policy discussions and conversations. We will feature over 20 articles, including photojournalism submissions, that cover a variety of topics internationally and domestically. Our submissions include policy analyses, op-eds, and research analyses. Our authors undergo a rigorous editorial process that begins at the start of April. Our team of designers then completes the final version of the publications. We utilize a local organization, Chicago Printworks, to produce the actual publication. expense name: Planting Justice Series 1: Environmental Rights and Land Sovereignty
description:
This event will focus on environmental justice and land rights, with a case study on Colombia. Attendees will engage in hands-on activities like making potted plants while discussing the intersection of environmental conservation, land sovereignty, and community empowerment. Speakers will highlight the role of African descendant communities and grassroots movements in advocating for land rights and environmental protection.

CJPA aims to partner with LVEJO’s - Their mission and accomplishments align perfectly with the event’s focus on environmental justice, land rights, and community empowerment. Their history of grassroots activism, food sovereignty initiatives, and environmental remediation provides a rich foundation for meaningful discussions and activities tied to the event's goals.

Activities included in the event -  this will  be a two part series event on two consecuitve fridays in April

Event 1 - Hands-On Activity: Making Potted Plants - LVEJO’s Semillas de Justicia Community Garden is a prime example of reclaiming contaminated land and transforming it into a thriving green space.Representatives from LVEJO will lead the potted plant activity, sharing their expertise in sustainable gardening techniques while discussing how urban agriculture can empower communities to reclaim land and promote food sovereignty.This activity could highlight how ancestral farming practices are preserved and passed on through such initiatives.

Event 2 -  Land Justice & Global Connections - LVEJO’s work in addressing environmental racism in Little Village mirrors struggles faced by descendant communities in Colombia. Both involve fighting for land rights, resisting industrial exploitation, and advocating for community-led solutions. In a lecture / workshop LVEJO will provide a comparative perspective, showcasing how local efforts in Chicago connect to global movements for land sovereignty and environmental justice. Speakers are TBD but we are in talks with Juliana Pino (Deputy Director) or Kim Wasserman (Executive Director) to discuss how community-led efforts can reclaim land, protect health, and create sustainable futures.
speaker: YES - WOMEN

expense name: Global Drug Policy: Perspectives for Reform
description:
This event will focus on drug policy reform in Chicago, connecting local harm reduction efforts with global approaches. Discussions will explore the environmental and social impacts of punitive drug policies, alternative strategies like harm reduction, and science-based solutions to substance use challenges. Attendees will engage in workshops, panel discussions, and interactive dialogues to understand how Chicago can lead in adopting progressive drug policies.

Partner Organization: Chicago Recovery Alliance (CRA)

The Chicago Recovery Alliance is a pioneering harm reduction organization that provides services such as naloxone distribution, syringe exchange, and fentanyl testing. They operate mobile outreach units across Chicago neighborhoods, focusing on reducing drug-related harm and building community trust. CRA emphasizes public health approaches over punitive measures to address substance use challenges.

CRA will lead a workshop on harm reduction practices, such as naloxone training and safer drug use strategies. Bring awareness on their mobile outreach model as an example of effective community-based interventions. CRA representatives,  Executive Director John Werning (TBD), will share insights on how harm reduction policies have saved lives in Chicago and discuss the challenges of implementing these programs in underserved areas.
speaker: YES

expense name: Circles of Peace: Restorative Justice in Action
description:
Centered around restorative justice practices, this event will feature peace circles as a tool for community healing and social change. Attendees will participate in interactive workshops led by local restorative justice practitioners from Chicago’s South Side. Discussions will address systemic issues such as the school-to-prison pipeline and explore how restorative practices can build stronger, more equitable communities.

Partner Organization: Precious Blood Ministry of Reconciliation (PBMR) - based in Chicago’s Back of the Yards neighborhood and is dedicated to fostering healing and repairing relationships through restorative justice practices. Their initiatives include peace circles, community-building efforts, and addressing harm caused by violence and systemic inequities. PBMR emphasizes Indigenous teachings and proactive strategies to create a culture of connectivity where all community members thrive.

Workshop Facilitators: PBMR will lead peace circle workshops, teaching attendees how to use circles for conflict resolution, grief processing, and collective decision-making. They will share their experience in using peace circles to address harm and build stronger community bonds. Representatives from PBMR will join discussions on how restorative justice practices address systemic issues like the school-to-prison pipeline and foster equity in underserved communities. PBMR will also have a booth showcasing their programs, such as Just Peace, and provide resources for attendees interested in implementing restorative practices in their own communities.

Speaker: Emmanuel Andre (Co-Founder of Circles & Ciphers) to discuss the transformative power of peace circles in Chicago’s neighborhoods
speaker: YES - POC

description:
Curated from a year of in-depth research, rigorous debate, and nuanced writing, the annual Chicago Policy Print Edition encapsulates the very best of our staff's published work. Each article, handpicked for its relevance and impact, reflects the commitment of our scholars, researchers, and writers. This collection is not just a testament to academic rigor; it's a mirror to the ever-evolving political landscape, capturing the most pressing policy challenges and innovative solutions of our time. With its blend of analytical insights and accessible prose, the Print Edition is an essential read for policy enthusiasts, practitioners, and casual readers alike. It is also used as a recruitement tool for prospective students and as a compilation of Harris student impact more broadly. 

NOTE: Although this initiative occurs in the spring quarter, it is our single largest organizational expense. As such, we aim to engage in budgeting best practices and ask for a portion of HSG funding each quarter to allocate towards this expense.
speaker: NA

description:

This event will aim to connect students to tangible job opportunities and networking within the field of policy communication. 

NOTE: Although this event takes place in the spring quarter, it is one of our largest organizational expenses aside from the print edition itself. As such, we aim to engage in budgeting best practices and ask for a portion of HSG funding each quarter to allocate towards this expense.

A tentative course outline is written below:
-What is financial modelling and its common uses (valuation, budgeting, scenario analysis)

-Valuation Techniques (DCF and multiples)
-Scenario & Sensitivity Analysis (Differing assumptions, goal seek)

expense name: Panel Discussion - Broken Peace: What's next?
description: This panel discussion will examine the political, humanitarian, and strategic consequences of post-ceasefire failures, exploring why such agreements unravel and what that means for the future of conflict resolution. Bringing together leading experts, including John Mearsheimer American political scientist, Rashid Khalidi a Palestinian-American historian of the Middle East, and Maliha Chisti an expert in peacebuilding, security and development - this discussion will provide historical context, political analysis, and insights into the lived realities on the ground and what to expect.

description:
The Health Nexus Initiative (HNI) Kick-Off Mixer is designed to introduce the newly recognized Health Nexus Initiative to the Harris community. The event will create awareness about HNI's mission to explore and advance global health policy, emphasizing interdisciplinary collaboration across climate change, technology, education, livelihoods, and more.

Students will have the opportunity to meet our Executive Board, understand HNI’s vision and programming plans for the year, and learn about ways to get involved. The event will foster meaningful dialogue, spark innovative ideas, and facilitate networking among Harris students interested in health policy and interdisciplinary approaches.

We invite all participants to come prepared with their ideas, curiosity, and questions. Light snacks and beverages will be served to encourage relaxed and engaging conversations.

Objectives of the Event:

Introduce the Harris community to the HNI mission and leadership.

Encourage student participation and involvement in upcoming HNI activities.

Foster networking and collaboration among students passionate about health policy and related fields.
speaker: FALSE

expense name: Navigating Uncertainty: Global Health Careers in a Shifting Policy Landscape
description:
The global health job market has been profoundly affected by recent geopolitical shifts, funding realignments, and evolving governance structures. From the U.S. withdrawal from the World Health Organization (WHO) to the shutdown of critical USAID programs under the Trump Administration, these changes have disrupted traditional career pathways and reshaped opportunities in global health policy, research, and implementation.

This panel discussion aims to help students navigate the uncertainties of global health careers in this evolving landscape. Featuring experts from global health organizations, policymakers, and academic leaders, the conversation will explore how funding streams, international collaborations, and policy priorities have shifted and what this means for students looking to build impactful careers in global health.

The in-person panel will feature two experts, one from the University of Chicago and another from a global health research/philanthropic organisation (possibly from RTI International or MacArthur Foundation). Panelists will discuss the challenges posed by shifting U.S. global health policies, the future of multilateral collaborations, and the emergence of new funding and employment opportunities in non-traditional spaces, including philanthropic organizations, think tanks, and regional health initiatives. The discussion will also provide practical insights on how students can position themselves for success in this uncertain environment—whether by building cross-sectoral expertise, exploring alternative funding mechanisms, or leveraging policy and research skills in new ways.
speaker: TRUE

description: In the 2023-24 academic year, IDPA hosted five faculty lunches with Harris professors in the international development space. These events were extremely well attended and students mentioned they were highly useful opportunities in gaining a deeper understanding of applied academic research, networking with professors, and gaining exposure to emergent issues in the field. While these were targeted to intimate audiences of 25 last year in order to maximize networking potential, spots were filled rapidly within a few days of marketing. Given the consistent positive feedback and desire for continued access to smaller audiences with professors, we wish to make this a bi-quarterly event with an increased capacity (30 students) in order to strengthen student-faculty relationships. As evidenced by the attendance in the Fall 2024 and Winter 2025 quarter, these events are highly anticipated.

expense name: Policy Roundtable: Africa’s Role in Global Sustainability
description: This engaging panel discussion will bring together African entrepreneurs, American scholars, and students who have worked in Africa to share their insights on Africa’s contributions to renewable energy and sustainable development. In collaboration with Booth Africa, the event seeks to secure credible speakers to ensure a high-quality and impactful discussion. The roundtable will explore how Africa is shaping the global sustainability agenda while fostering collaboration between academia, policy, and industry. With diverse speakers and an open Q&A session, attendees will gain practical knowledge about innovative approaches and policy frameworks, build meaningful connections for future partnerships, and take away actionable ideas to support Africa’s leadership in sustainability. This event aims to spark impactful conversations, promote diversity, and position the Harris School and UChicago as a key player in global discussions on Africa’s development and engagement.
speaker: Yes. There'll be a woman or two. There'll be several entrepreneurs from Africa

expense name: Conflict Resolution Workshop: Lessons from Africa
description:
This interactive workshop brings together experienced practitioners who are deeply engaged in conflict resolution and peacebuilding efforts across war-torn regions of Africa, including Sudan, Kenya, and Somalia. The purpose of the event is to shed light on African-led approaches to resolving conflict, rebuilding trust, and fostering sustainable peace in communities affected by violence, displacement, and political instability.

Participants will learn from real-life experiences and fieldwork insights shared by frontline peacebuilders. Through dynamic discussions, case study explorations, and hands-on activities, the workshop will explore traditional and innovative African methods of mediation, community reconciliation, and post-conflict healing.

This is not a lecture-style event—attendees will be encouraged to engage directly with the speakers, share their perspectives, and collaboratively analyze challenges and solutions. The goal is to foster a deeper understanding of context-driven conflict resolution strategies that can inform both local and global peacebuilding practices.
speaker: Yes. There'll be a four women. There'll be practitioners from Africa.

description:
Organized by The African Perspective in collaboration with the East African Students Association (EASA)

Join us for a vibrant campus-wide celebration of Africa’s rich cultures, innovative spirit, and global contributions. The Africa Day Celebration will feature a dynamic cultural parade showcasing traditional attire, music, and dance from across the continent. A keynote speaker—an esteemed thought leader in African innovation and global development—will anchor the event with powerful reflections on Africa's past, present, and future.

Interactive exhibitions will spotlight African-led innovations in technology, sustainability, and the arts, highlighting the ingenuity and resilience that define the continent. This is more than a celebration—it's an educational experience that brings the UChicago community together to honor Africa’s diversity and amplify African voices on campus.

By collaborating with EASA, we aim to create an inclusive, high-impact event that fosters cross-cultural understanding and deepens appreciation for Africa’s contributions to the world. With your support, we can make Africa Day a flagship celebration of unity, identity, and forward-thinking excellence at the University of Chicago.
speaker: Yes. There'll be 7 woman vendors . There'll be African, Asian, American, and European students

expense name: Trip to the Swahili Institute at Chicago
description:
This experiential learning trip to the Swahili Institute in Chicago is designed to deepen students' understanding of African languages and their role in shaping cultural identity and cross-cultural communication. With a focus on Swahili—a language spoken by over 100 million people across East and Central Africa—this visit will provide participants with a unique opportunity to engage with Africa’s linguistic heritage through interactive sessions led by language experts and cultural educators.

The purpose of this trip is to create space for dialogue around the importance of language in fostering mutual understanding, dismantling stereotypes, and promoting global citizenship. Participants will take part in guided activities that include Swahili language immersion, discussions on African oral traditions, and the role of language in unifying diverse communities.

This initiative supports the University of Chicago’s broader commitment to diversity, equity, and global engagement. With funding, we will be able to provide transportation, materials for interactive learning, and refreshments, ensuring full accessibility to all interested students. The experience will enrich academic and cultural exploration on campus and strengthen ties between students and Chicago’s African diaspora institutions.
speaker: Yes. There'll be a woman or two. There'll be African, Asian, European, and American students

description:
The New Scramble for Africa: Charting a Way Forward is a flagship event designed to examine Africa’s evolving role in global politics and economics amidst increasing international competition for its resources and influence. Featuring a keynote address by renowned scholar James Robinson, the event will include dynamic panel discussions with faculty, students, and practitioners on critical topics such as governance strategies, resource exploitation, sustainable development, and Africa’s positioning in global engagements. The discussions will explore how Africa can balance foreign interests with national development priorities, foster equitable partnerships, and ensure that African voices shape the continent’s future.

In collaboration with ACSA (African and Caribbean Students Association), East African Students Association (EASA), and Booth Africa, we will promote the event and leverage shared resources to ensure broad engagement and participation. Attendees will gain a deeper understanding of the historical and current dimensions of international engagement with Africa and leave with actionable strategies to support sustainable and equitable development. The event will also create opportunities for building cross-disciplinary partnerships between academic institutions, policy organizations, and industry players, while showcasing diverse perspectives through the inclusion of African scholars, practitioners, and students.

By fostering critical dialogue on Africa’s global positioning and governance challenges, this event aims to inspire actionable solutions that prioritize Africa’s growth and empowerment. It will be a cornerstone of impactful discourse at the Harris School and UChicago at large, promoting a deeper understanding of Africa’s priorities and aspirations in a rapidly shifting global landscape.
speaker: Yes. There'll be a woman or two. There'll be POC, too

description:
The Movie Screening event offers a unique opportunity to experience the power of African cinema while engaging in meaningful discussions about identity, history, development, and cultural exchange. The event will feature a carefully selected African film that highlights the richness and complexity of African stories, followed by a moderated discussion led by knowledgeable faculty and students. This dialogue will encourage attendees to reflect on the film’s cultural, historical, and social significance, exploring how its narrative connects to broader themes of African resilience, identity, and global engagement.

For Harris School students, this event provides a distinct benefit by offering an immersive lens into African socio-political and cultural dynamics. It complements their academic studies by illustrating how storytelling can influence policy, shape societal norms, and drive conversations about development and equity. Through this event, Harris students will gain insights into the intersection of culture and public policy, fostering a deeper understanding of how narratives can inform and inspire effective policymaking.

Participants will leave with an enriched perspective on African cinema’s ability to address pressing themes, inspire change, and bridge cultural divides, while building meaningful connections within a diverse and engaged community. This event is not just a celebration of African storytelling but also an essential platform for critical learning and dialogue.

description:
Unum general meetings are held for members interested in improving public speaking and debate skills. These would take the form of meetings hosted in Keller classrooms with pre-prepared informational and debate presentations. In our studies at Harris, we have found that many of our classmates are incredibly intelligent and thoughtful, but struggle with speaking out- whether due to language barriers, shyness, etc. Before we can address people's willingness to debate political and policy topics, we have to help people get comfortable speaking in general. We believe these events would go a long way towards setting out a framework for even the most novice or shy speakers to become more confident and become thought leaders in the Harris community.

The initial public speaking training event in Winter Quarter was well received by those that did attend, but due to lower than expected turnout for our initial meeting, instead of scheduling a Part 2 to the original, we will try to revamp and rerun the original meeting so that more students can attend. We have revised our request down to account for this.
speaker: N/A

description:
Unum members who have expressed interest and competence in debate (either through Unum or outside experience) participate in debates with peers at other policy schools/universities on subjects such as free speech, the Constitution, and other subjects relevant to politics and policy. Funding requests for these events cover transportation and lodging from Chicago to the host school. Unum has hosted these events in the past as interest and scheduling permit. This event would be held in person at Cornell University in Ithaca, NY. 

Unum has had great success with these events in the past and has built positive relationships with peers at these schools that we would like to continue to maintain. Cornell counterparts have generously offered to cover local hosting costs, but we would like to request additional funds to enable as many members to attend as possible, and to remove any financial barriers.
speaker: N/A

expense name: Speaker event - Prof. Leila Brammer on Viewpoint Diversity
description:
(NOTE: Due to scheduling conflicts, we weren't able to host this event during Winter Quarter as planned. We're leaving it here for transparency and because it is something we may still want to pursue, but we understand that funding may not be provided a second time. We also note that Rich Delewsky, who initially coordinated with us for initial planning, is no longer the Unum advisor, which may complicate matters. We are also revising attendance down to account for revised expectations.)
Prof. Leila Brammer is a professor at the UChicago College who is director of the Parrhesia undergraduate program, providing students with the resources to have important conversations about vital topics in society and encouraging viewpoint diversity and civil debate. (See https://mag.uchicago.edu/law-policy-society/figure-speech) Prof. Brammer spoke at this year's Harris orientation, and the Office of Student Engagement and Belonging has expressed great interest in having her speak again. Given its mission, Unum reached out to partner with SEB and would be honored to host Prof. Brammer. We would be hosting two general meetings prior to this speaker to prepare students for Prof. Brammer's speech andw ill also be working with her to tailor the material to a public policy audience in particular. This event would go a long way towards providing an important venue for Harris students to debate important political and policy topics both at UChicago and beyond, and would help continue to support Office of Student Engagement and Belonging's mission and programming.
speaker: Yes - speaker is a woman
